text: One of the common features of the Obama Care Program is its prohibition of insurance companies that are denied coverage to persons with pre-existing circumstances. With health care formed as a major issue in the mid-term, the Democrats now paint Republicans as opponents of this popular protection. "Protection of pre-existing conditions is a matter of life or death," said Sun. John Tester, D-Mont., in a Facebook ad that showed Montana with a pre-existing situation. "I have fought to protect coverage from pre-existing conditions, but Matt Rosendale supports plans that need not be covered by them." Turns out Rosendale supports such plans. President Donald Trump ' s short-term plans, and the reorganization of the health-care market by Republican legislators, have led to an increase in smaller, less profitable schemes. In August, the Trump Administration issued a rule allowing insurers to extend the duration of short-term insurance schemes. These so-called "short-term and limited-term" plans, originally designed to fill temporary gaps in coverage for up to three months, are exempt from the pre-existing coverage base. Under Trump, interim plans can now last up to 364 days, and can be renewed up to three times. Meanwhile, Republican legislators voted to abolish a tax penalty applied by the Affordable Care Act to Americans who chose not to provide comprehensive coverage. The penalty begins in 2019. These measures have opened the door for consumers to drop the full coverage, or to purchase "short-term" plans without penalty, which may be renewable for up to three years and do not have to cover pre-existing circumstances. In the absence of pre-existing coverage, insurance companies are more free to formulate this category of insurance policy. Companies in the short-term market may choose not to insure or renew the applicant because of sanitary conditions. Or higher premiums may be imposed on the basis of health status, gender or other factors. "But then they will give up coverage of any health services related to those conditions."
